question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-12-12 17:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/30763). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

According to the WHO, the Emergency Committee of the International Health Regulations (IHR) [consists](https://www.who.int/news-room/questions-and-answers/item/emergencies-international-health-regulations-and-emergency-committees) "of international experts who provide technical advice to the WHO Director-General in the context of a 'public health emergency of international concern' (PHEIC)." Important factors the Emergency Committee weighs in its deliberation process are:

1. risks to human health
2. international spread of the outbreak, and
3. interference with international travel.

The final determination of a PHEIC is made by the Director-General of the WHO.

In recent years, the WHO has declared a PHEIC for the [2022-2023](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022%E2%80%932023_mpox_outbreak) and [2023-2024](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023%E2%80%932024_mpox_epidemic) mpox outbreaks, the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic), the 2018-2020 [ebola outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kivu_Ebola_epidemic), and the 2015-2016 [Zika epidemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_Zika_virus_epidemic).

With respect to H5, at the time of this question the WHO [assesses the risk](https://www.who.int/emergencies/disease-outbreak-news/item/2024-DON512) as follows:

> Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in birds, there is a risk for sporadic infections in mammals and humans due to exposure to infected animals (including livestock), or contaminated environments and thus, further human cases are not unexpected.  Influenza A infection has been rarely reported in bovine species and spread among dairy cattle herds in four U.S. States is being assessed. Previously, there have been human infections with other avian influenza subtypes following exposure to infected mammals.

> Since the virus has not acquired mutations that facilitate transmission among humans and based on available information, WHO assesses the public health risk to the general population posed by this virus to be low and for occupationally exposed persons the risk of infection is considered low-to-moderate.

> There are no specific vaccines for preventing influenza A(H5N1) virus infection in humans. Candidate vaccines to prevent H5 infection in humans have been developed for pandemic preparedness purposes. Close analysis of the epidemiological situation, further characterization of the most recent viruses (from human cases and animal) and comprehensive investigations around human cases are critical to assess associated risk and to adjust risk management measures in a timely manner.

For more information please see:

* US Centers for Disease Control [H5 Bird Flu: Current Situation](https://www.cdc.gov/bird-flu/situation-summary/index.html)
* WHO [Risk assessments and summaries of influenza at the human-animal interface](https://www.who.int/teams/global-influenza-programme/avian-influenza/monthly-risk-assessment-summary)
* Pan American Health Organization [Epidemiological alerts and updates](https://www.paho.org/en/epidemiological-alerts-and-updates)

> A PHEIC is defined in the IHR (2005) as, “an extraordinary event which is determined to constitute a public health risk to other States through the international spread of disease and to potentially require a coordinated international response”. This definition implies a situation that is:

> * serious, sudden, unusual or unexpected;
> * carries implications for public health beyond the affected State’s national border; and
> * may require immediate international action.

If WHO changes this definition in a manner that a panel of Metaculus Admins determines to be substantial, this question may be either clarified or annulled.

For purposes of this question, any subtype of H5 (e.g., H5N1, H5Nx) is acceptable if encompassed by the PHEIC.

The company plans to begin human trials by year-end.

summary: All experts agree that the probability of the WHO declaring H5 avian influenza a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) before January 1, 2026, is low. The base rate for such a declaration in the context of avian influenza is effectively zero, as it has never occurred despite decades of global outbreaks and occasional zoonotic spillover. As of mid-October 2025, the WHO and CDC continue to assess the risk to the general population as low, with no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission, and no international clusters indicative of a higher threat. Experts consistently note that the main procedural and epidemiological trigger for a PHEIC—efficient or sustained human-to-human transmission—has not been met. Other factors, such as the introduction of a WHO 'pandemic emergency' category above PHEIC, generally reinforce a high threshold for a PHEIC declaration. While there is acknowledgment of ongoing animal outbreaks, heightened international surveillance, and some marginal increases in risk due to preparedness activities and the theoretical chance of viral mutation, these are not considered sufficient to change the overall outlook. Individual probabilities from the expert summaries primarily cluster between 6% and 7%, with one outlier at 13%. The consensus in the forecasts is that barring an unexpected, major epidemiological shift—such as a cluster of documented human-to-human transmissions with significant disease—no PHEIC will be declared before 2026.
